title: Rust trap
data:
| ^ rust trap [![Rust trap.png](/images/7/73/Rust_trap.png)](/wiki/File:Rust_trap.png) |                               |
| ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------ | ----------------------------- |
| Generates                                                                            | Anywhere                      |
| Effect                                                                               | [wets](/wiki/Wet "Wet") items |

A **rust trap** is a [trap](/wiki/Trap "Trap") that sprays you with water, making your items [wet](/wiki/Wet "Wet") and possibly [rusting](/wiki/Rust "Rust") them.

[ ]

## Contents

- [1 Effects](#Effects)

  - [1.1 On the player](#On_the_player)
  - [1.2 On monsters](#On_monsters)

- [2 Remove](#Remove)

- [3 Strategy](#Strategy)

- [4 History](#History)

- [5 Messages](#Messages)

- [6 Variants](#Variants)

- [7 References](#References)

## Effects

- *Main article: [Wet](/wiki/Wet "Wet")*

### On the player

Any worn or wielded item can potentially become wet. For unprotected [iron](/wiki/Iron "Iron") items, this will cause rusting. Whenever the trap is activated, it randomly picks an armor slot to target, instead of looping over every armor slot. This means no item is strictly 'guaranteed' to become wet.

If you are [polymorphed](/wiki/Polymorph "Polymorph") into an [iron golem](/wiki/Iron_golem "Iron golem"), you will take damage equal to your monster form's maximum HP, killing your monster form and reverting you to your natural form. The [half physical damage](/wiki/Half_physical_damage "Half physical damage") extrinsic applies. [\[1\]](#cite_note-1)

### On monsters

Items worn or wielded are affected, similarly to those of the player.

[Gremlins](/wiki/Gremlin "Gremlin") like to use these traps to multiply. Iron golems will be instantly destroyed by these traps. [\[2\]](#cite_note-2)

## Remove

[Dig](/wiki/Dig "Dig") a pit into the ground while standing on the trap, then fill the pit.

## Strategy

In the early game, you should wear a [cloak](/wiki/Cloak "Cloak") to protect your body armor.

You can use a rust trap as an infinite, if somewhat slow, source of blanking scrolls and spellbooks and diluting potions, by wielding them, removing any other rustable gear, and repeatedly triggering the trap.

## History

Rust traps were added in [NetHack 1.3d](/wiki/NetHack_1.3d "NetHack 1.3d")

## Messages

- A gush of water hits you on the \<body part>!

  Your armor in the corresponding slot takes water damage.

- A gush of water hits you!

  The trap hit your body armor slot, or you are an iron golem.

- You are covered with rust!

  You are an iron golem and were hit by the trap. Your monster form will be killed unless you have [half physical damage](/wiki/Half_physical_damage "Half physical damage").

- A gush of water hits \<monster> on the \<body part>!

  A monster's armor in the corresponding slot takes water damage.

- \<monster> falls to pieces!

  An iron golem was hit by the trap and died.

- May \<monster> rust in peace.

  [As above, but the iron golem was tame and was out of sight.](/wiki/YAFM "YAFM")

## Variants

In [SLASH'EM](/wiki/SLASH%27EM "SLASH'EM") and [dNetHack](/wiki/DNetHack "DNetHack"), untrapping a rust trap will turn the trap into a [fountain](/wiki/Fountain "Fountain") if successful.

## References

1. [↑](#cite_ref-1) [src/trap.c in NetHack 3.6.6, line 1118](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.6_Released/src/trap.c#L1118)
2. [↑](#cite_ref-2) [src/trap.c in NetHack 3.6.6, line 2320](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.6_Released/src/trap.c#L2320)

[![This article has been updated to reflect NetHack 3.6.6. Click here for more information.](/images/5/57/Nh366-icon.png)](/wiki/NetHackWiki:Next_version "This article has been updated to reflect NetHack 3.6.6. Click here for more information.")
html:
Rust trap

From NetHackWiki
Jump to navigation Jump to search
^ rust trap
Generates Anywhere
Effect wets items

A rust trap is a trap that sprays you with water, making your items wet and possibly rusting them.

Contents

  • 1 Effects
    • 1.1 On the player
    • 1.2 On monsters
  • 2 Remove
  • 3 Strategy
  • 4 History
  • 5 Messages
  • 6 Variants
  • 7 References

Effects

Main article: Wet

On the player

Any worn or wielded item can potentially become wet. For unprotected iron items, this will cause rusting. Whenever the trap is activated, it randomly picks an armor slot to target, instead of looping over every armor slot. This means no item is strictly 'guaranteed' to become wet.

If you are polymorphed into an iron golem, you will take damage equal to your monster form's maximum HP, killing your monster form and reverting you to your natural form. The half physical damage extrinsic applies. [1]

On monsters

Items worn or wielded are affected, similarly to those of the player.

Gremlins like to use these traps to multiply. Iron golems will be instantly destroyed by these traps. [2]

Remove

Dig a pit into the ground while standing on the trap, then fill the pit.

Strategy

In the early game, you should wear a cloak to protect your body armor.

You can use a rust trap as an infinite, if somewhat slow, source of blanking scrolls and spellbooks and diluting potions, by wielding them, removing any other rustable gear, and repeatedly triggering the trap.

History

Rust traps were added in NetHack 1.3d

Messages

A gush of water hits you on the <body part>!
Your armor in the corresponding slot takes water damage.
A gush of water hits you!
The trap hit your body armor slot, or you are an iron golem.
You are covered with rust!
You are an iron golem and were hit by the trap. Your monster form will be killed unless you have half physical damage.
A gush of water hits <monster> on the <body part>!
A monster's armor in the corresponding slot takes water damage.
<monster> falls to pieces!
An iron golem was hit by the trap and died.
May <monster> rust in peace.
As above, but the iron golem was tame and was out of sight.

Variants

In SLASH'EM and dNetHack, untrapping a rust trap will turn the trap into a fountain if successful.

References

  1. ↑ src/trap.c in NetHack 3.6.6, line 1118
  2. ↑ src/trap.c in NetHack 3.6.6, line 2320
